bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Eugene R. Whitmore, November 26, 1917

div1.p: Carter expresses regret that he will not be able to hear Whitmore present his paper. He discusses the difficulty of yellow fever diagnosis and recommends a pathologist for yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Eugene R. Whitmore, November 26, 1917
div1.opener:
Relative
Whitmore
November 26, 1917.
Dr. Eugene R. Whitmore,
Army Medical School,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Dr. Whitmore:
div1.p:
I was not glad to get your letter of the 23rd.
I will probably leave this place on the evening of December 3rd.
so I wont be able to hear your paper and I wanted to hear it.

What made you go back on yourself and not read
it in January or February as you first said? I am keeping my word
to be in Baltimore in the early part of December. I will arrive
in the afternoon of December 5th. I would like to have heard
not only the paper but the debate on it on the Hopkins Pathologist,
however I am so used to not getting what I want that I have really
almost ceased to mind it.

I understand from Dr. Gorgas that Guiteras did
not find any Yellow fever in or around Maracaybo but that he did
find some cases, people whom he saw sick and on whom he did anti-
topsis, at Coro.

He, Guiteras, thought the disease reported as
Yellow Fever last November and December in Barbadoes to be Weil's
disease but he did not prove it. If we accept the clinical descrip-
tion and the epidemiology as given by the British Health Officer
and by Guiteras later as correct, it was not yellow fever. There
is almostways a chance of error however in judging all things we see
2
from the eyes of nature because if we accept it it is a very big
provisor

We have no laboratory diagnosis for yellow fever unfortunately
and I not only confess that there are individuals cases which I cannot
diagnosticate but assert that there are such cases in which the di-
agnosis is impossible at present. On the other hand. I do not think
there can be any considerable number of cases, as an epidemic, in which
diagnosis is not possible.

When Gorgas wrote me last spring about taking up this work
with Guiteras, I suggested taking Darling as the Pathologist of the
party if he were available. If he would not I asked him to consult
you or Dr. Welch for a Pathologist. A Dr. Taylor is with Guiteras
in this capacity, of whom I know nothing except that he has done
some very good work on the Cuban mosquitoes. The extra cantonment
malaria work however rendered it impossible for me to go, although
I would have given my years to have looked into the socalled “Coun-
try Fevers” of the French Antilles and their Fraver Roja of Venezu-
ela which I suspect comprise at least two or three epidemiological
entities.
div1.closer: Yours very sincerely, Assistant Surgeon General. HRC/IR
